subs.text: June 29
@AnneMWolke @MaggieBlackhawk This time, the Court even provided Congress with sample language to use in amending Public Law 280: [link]
subs.rawText: @AnneMWolke @MaggieBlackhawk This time, the Court even provided Congress with sample language to use in amending Public Law 280: https://t.co/5W2f3gtAps

subs.text: @capannemazing @MaggieBlackhawk “A State lacks criminal jurisdiction over crimes by or against Indians in Indian Country, unless the State complies with the procedures to obtain tribal consent outlined in 25 U.S.C. § 1321, and, where necessary, amends its constitution or statutes pursuant to 25 U.S.C. § 1324.”
subs.rawText: @capannemazing @MaggieBlackhawk “A State lacks criminal jurisdiction over crimes by or against Indians in Indian Country, unless the State complies with the procedures to obtain tribal consent outlined in 25 U.S.C. § 1321, and, where necessary, amends its constitution or statutes pursuant to 25 U.S.C. § 1324.”

subs.text: @capannemazing @MaggieBlackhawk (That is the example legislative language provided in #Gorsuch’s dissent, found on page 69 of the PDF: [link])
subs.rawText:
@capannemazing @MaggieBlackhawk (That is the example legislative language provided in #Gorsuch’s dissent, found on page 69 of the PDF:

https://t.co/0U55gTgnA3)

subs.text: @capannemazing @MaggieBlackhawk “Nor must Congress stand by as this Court sows needless confusion across the country. Even the Court acknowledges that Congress can undo its decision and preempt state authority at any time. … And Congress could do exactly that with (that) simple amendment to Public Law 280.”

subs.text: Given the timing of its release, one must wonder if today’s 5-4 #SCOTUS ruling in #Oklahoma v. #Castro_Huerta was decided mostly for concern over justice in #IndianCountry, or rather as a hedge against tribal governments allowing #abortions to be performed in their territories.
subs.rawText: Given the timing of its release, one must wonder if today’s 5-4 #SCOTUS ruling in #Oklahoma v. #Castro_Huerta was decided mostly for concern over justice in #IndianCountry, or rather as a hedge against tribal governments allowing #abortions to be performed in their territories.

@KelmitTheFrog @DorisMurdock @The_Kris_Guin @stevesilberman @Uber @lyft Effective outsourced customer service at this scale (and price point) is nearly impossible (since any authority over ‘$5 coupons’ given to agents open to mass fraud).

They really need a dedicated manager in _each_ city (who is able to be contacted) to deal with issues like this.

subs.text: June 17

@DruidicFireball @SkepticalGinger Did they apologize for not saluting?

Did they belatedly salute when they looked up and realized they were addressing a superior officer?

Did they do anything to acknowledge a mistake? 

She _didn’t punish_ the person; if a pattern their NCO should enquire, and train as needed.
subs.rawText:
@DruidicFireball @SkepticalGinger Did they apologize for not saluting?

Did they belatedly salute when they looked up and realized they were addressing a superior officer?

Did they do anything to acknowledge a mistake? 

She _didn’t punish_ the person; if a pattern their NCO should enquire, and train as needed.

subs.text:
@DruidicFireball @SkepticalGinger I didn’t mean to imply that anything habitual should be inferred, and for the person’s NCO to make that judgement requires _some_ knowledge of individual events.

A pattern of ‘honest mistakes’ can imply carelessness, fatigue, stress, etc.; each may require different mitigations.
subs.rawText:
@DruidicFireball @SkepticalGinger I didn’t mean to imply that anything habitual should be inferred, and for the person’s NCO to make that judgement requires _some_ knowledge of individual events.

A pattern of ‘honest mistakes’ can imply carelessness, fatigue, stress, etc.; each may require different mitigations.

subs.text:
@SkepticalGinger @MortenKathy @HeyTweetJon … and to the officer themselves, in that they hold a commission from the United States Congress, and thus are an _official_ symbol representing the nation itself - much as is the flag.

For the civilians: that’s why O-1s get saluted but seasoned combat veteran E-9s do not.
subs.rawText:
@SkepticalGinger @MortenKathy @HeyTweetJon … and to the officer themselves, in that they hold a commission from the United States Congress, and thus are an _official_ symbol representing the nation itself - much as is the flag.

For the civilians: that’s why O-1s get saluted but seasoned combat veteran E-9s do not.

subs.text: @SkepticalGinger @MortenKathy @HeyTweetJon Likewise, our oaths of allegiance and office are to our constitution, not to the home/mother/father-land, and not to our head of state or head of government (which yes, are strangely the same person in the United States).
subs.rawText: @SkepticalGinger @MortenKathy @HeyTweetJon Likewise, our oaths of allegiance and office are to our constitution, not to the home/mother/father-land, and not to our head of state or head of government (which yes, are strangely the same person in the United States).

subs.text: @HeyTweetJon @SkepticalGinger In the USN at least, one would simply hold the salute until passing the higher-ranking officer and then drop it, just as if the admiral’s back was turned toward the person saluting or if that person were passing / passed by the national ensign (flag).
subs.rawText: @HeyTweetJon @SkepticalGinger In the USN at least, one would simply hold the salute until passing the higher-ranking officer and then drop it, just as if the admiral’s back was turned toward the person saluting or if that person were passing / passed by the national ensign (flag).

subs.text:
@SkepticalGinger @DruidicFireball If someone is too careless to perform something as simple as a salute, what other things might they slip up on later?

It’s not like you dropped the kid for push-ups on tarmac, after all.
subs.rawText:
@SkepticalGinger @DruidicFireball If someone is too careless to perform something as simple as a salute, what other things might they slip up on later?

It’s not like you dropped the kid for push-ups on tarmac, after all.

subs.text: June 13

@JayD_JDee @ComEd The outages appear to be tons of separate small groups, in a swath following the storm’s path from the western / northwest suburbs (as far north as Lake Zurich) into southeastern Chicago.

Most of these outages will have to be investigated and repaired separately.
subs.rawText:
@JayD_JDee @ComEd The outages appear to be tons of separate small groups, in a swath following the storm’s path from the western / northwest suburbs (as far north as Lake Zurich) into southeastern Chicago.

Most of these outages will have to be investigated and repaired separately.

subs.text:

… but isolated areas with equipment damage could take quite a bit longer.

subs.text:
@Debkrol @aurabogado Risk:

Terminal > in seat while engines running

… but …

Boarding / unboarding > terminal > in seat while engines running

[_If_ shore ventilation is hooked up (those flexible yellow hoses from the JetWay) it’s still less effective than that provided by the engine bleed air.]
subs.rawText:
@Debkrol @aurabogado Risk:

Terminal > in seat while engines running

… but …

Boarding / unboarding > terminal > in seat while engines running

[_If_ shore ventilation is hooked up (those flexible yellow hoses from the JetWay) it’s still less effective than that provided by the engine bleed air.]
